Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Perception and Use of Infrared Radiation by Insects
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will investigate the ability of insects to detect and respond to infrared light, which is a type of electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths longer than that of visible light. It is known from insects as diverse as honeybees, beetles and butterflies that animals have evolved diverse strategies to perceive and utilize electromagnetic waves. Organs evolved for perceiving or controlling electromagnetic waves often surpass similar man-made devices in both sophistication and efficiency. To date, most of the focus in this area of research has been on the abilities of insects to perceive shorter wavelengths of light; much less is known about how animals respond to longer wavelengths, in part because the tools to investigate this end of the spectrum have only recently become commonly available. In this research, physicists and biologists will collaborate in studying a few model systems, including the antennae of moths and specialized wing scales of butterflies, to understand how insects can perceive and utilize infrared light. Understanding and harnessing natural design concepts through "biomimicry" will deepen our knowledge of complex biological systems and inspire ideas for creating new technologies. The research will provide training opportunities in nanotechnology for graduate students in biology and physics.

The objectives of the project are to understand the physical mechanisms underlying the ability of insects to perceive and respond to infrared light, and to obtain engineering insights that can be used to create novel infrared materials, devices and systems. Infrared signals may play a critical and underappreciated role in a wide variety of insect behaviors. This project will provide a quantitative understanding of insects' abilities to sense and respond to broadband thermal radiation and narrowband fingerprint infrared radiation by analyzing two systems: (1) Scent pads and patches on the wings of butterfly species in the hyperdiverse tribe Eumaeini (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae) that show extremely broadband, close-to-unity absorptivity/emissivity, and (2) Specialized sensilla on the antennae of different moth species that are able to capture infrared light with high wavelength-specificity and efficiency. The model insects will be studied using a multidisciplinary research platform. The infrared-sensing organs will be identified using single-sensillum electrophysiological recordings and behavioral bioassays with spectrally and temporally controlled infrared stimulation. The morphology of the infrared-sensing organs will be studied using scanning electron microscopy and X-ray micro-tomography. The optical properties of the sensilla will be studied using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, infrared microscopy, and finite-difference time-domain electromagnetic wave simulations. High-fidelity replicas of the infrared-sensing microstructures or their scaled models will be fabricated using nano- and micro-fabrication to systematically analyze how material properties, structures and arrangement of the sensilla affect the sensitivity and wavelength-specificity of infrared detection. Detailed studies of the mechanisms by which insects perceive and respond to infrared signals have not been carried out before, and a greater understanding of this phenomenon is likely to catalyze a new area of research for the scientific community. The project will expand our understanding of how natural selection can shape exquisitely adapted behaviors and structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Perception and Use of Infrared Radiation by Insects

The goals of our research are to understand the physical mechanisms underlying the ability of insects to perceive and use infrared light, to draw scientific and engineering lessons from these case studies, and to educate young scientists so that they can carry out interdisciplinary work across the boundary of the physical and life sciences. Key scientific contributions made with this award include: (1) A fundamental understanding of the interaction between insects and their electromagnetic environment.  Importantly, we have shown how exquisitely adapted micro- and nano-structures on the scales of butterfly wings can function to control sunlight and thermal radiation to keep living parts of the wing cool. (2) Discovery of novel sensing mechanisms that enable small insects to perceive light and heat.  This has included investigating how butterfly wings can function as a distributed sensor network for fast detection of light and thermal radiation, and how certain species of butterflies can see and respond to polarized light of different wavelengths. (3) Establishment of a comprehensive and multidisciplinary methodology (encompassing microscopy, spectroscopy, thermodynamic experiments, multiphysics modeling, full-wave simulations, lab behavior assays, and field studies) to study the interplay between small animals and electromagnetic environment. (4) Invention of high-throughput and high-yield techniques to manufacture biomimetic materials that emulate the optical and thermodynamic properties of structures discovered on insects.

In carrying out this project, we have engaged in a diversity of outreach activities involving education and technology transfer. The research has provided a comprehensive training for 4 graduate students, 3 research assistants and one undergraduate in optical microscopy and spectroscopy, design and implementation of behavioral assays, multiphysics modeling, full-wave simulations, and for the team at Columbia University, fabrication of functional biomimetic materials.  The PI, Naomi Pierce has given multiple public lectures, including one at the Museum of Science during their annual festivities for 'Caterpillar and butterfly days'.

For the Applied Physics team at Columbia University, the program has yielded two technological inventions (one provisional patent and one PCT patent application). They developed a biomimetic radiative-cooling roof coating that is able to substantially reduce roof temperature and thus reduce electricity usage during the summer time. They also developed a biomimetic radiative cooling fabric that offers a combination of cooling mechanisms (radiative, convective and evaporative cooling) that can be used to create ultra-thin cooling apparel and building materials.

Highlights of outcomes are as follows:

1. We discovered that the construction of the butterfly wing as well as the nanostructured wing scales lead to a highly non-uniform distribution of radiative cooling; as a result, wing regions containing living cells have the lowest temperature.

2. Through a series of behavioral studies on live butterflies, we found that butterfly wings can function as fast and sensitive sensors of temperature and light, and that butterflies use behavioral strategies to thermoregulate their wings within a suitable range of temperatures. A paper summarizing 1 and 2 is in press in Nature Communications.

3. We discovered that an Australian lycaenid butterfly, Jalmenus evagoras, can detect optical polarization. Our field studies show that J. evagoras prefer depolarized blue mock 'wings' to polarized ones, and our spectroscopic measurements show that the structural colors on the wings of female J. evagoras are less polarized than on the wings of males.

4. We developed a multi-spectral imaging platform to rapidly screen drawers of museum specimens of butterflies and moths under several wavelength bands of illumination.
